items.content_html:
Summary

Security teams need more configurability over who can bypass push protection to balance security and developer productivity effectively. By integrating secret scanning's push protection into repository rulesets, Application Security teams can provide fine-grained control over which users can approve requested bypasses. Developers will have the ability to request approval from authorized users to push a blocked secret.
items.title: Secret scanning push protection bypass rules

items.content_html:
Summary

With ISO 27001 as a foundation, GitHub is able to register as a participant in the Trusted Information Security Assessment Exchange (TISAX).

Intended Outcome

GitHub will achieve TISAX Assessment Level 2 for the assessment objectives and resulting TISAX labels of "Handling of information with high protection needs" and "Data protection". The outcome of this work is that GitHub Enterprise Cloud customers will be able to use GitHub to develop software while meeting TISAX compliance obligations.

How will it work?

GitHub GRC has already begun the registration process by registering as a TISAX Participant and we have defined an assessment scope. Next up, GRC is working with to identify a TISAX audit provider and will then undergo a TISAX assessment. The results of GitHub's assessment will then be made available to TISAX partners. Once certified, GitHub will add TISAX to customer facing documentation portals.
items.title: TISAX Compliance for Dotcom and GHEC

items.content_html:
Summary

Automatically enable the detection of transitive dependencies for Maven with a one-click set up through a repository's settings.

Intended Outcome

Dependency graph currently does not automatically detect transitive dependencies for Maven. Users can use a GitHub Action to detect and submit these dependencies to the dependency graph, but the discoverability of this action is low and the configuration hurdle can be high. A one-click enablement eliminates these hurdles for users and provides the dependency information they need.

How will it work?

Enabling Maven transitive dependency detection through a repository's settings page will run the Maven Dependency Submission Action using dynamic workflows. The repository will show the complete Maven dependencies in the dependency graph, and users will received Dependabot alerts for any known vulnerabilities. Users do not need to configure their own workflow files.

The initial release will be enablement at the repository level only. Future ships will include leveraging other detectors for other ecosystems and organisation-level enablement.
items.title: One-click enablement for Maven transitive dependency detection

items.content_html:
Summary

With enterprise managed users, more and more developers have to juggle a professional account and a personal account on GitHub.com. To switch between these accounts, developers must sign out of one and then sign in to the other. This can be particularly difficult for developers who frequently switch between those contexts.

To make switching between professional and personal accounts easier, we're building an account picker for GitHub.com that lets developers switch between accounts without signing out and signing in again.

Intended Outcome

It's easy for a developer to switch between their accounts on GitHub.com.

How will it work?

Up to 10 user sessions will be cached in the browser, and one will be considered active. Developers can switch between cached sessions, changing which one is active. Authorization, SAML, and similar per-account or per-session information are not shared between cached sessions, so there's no leakage of data between them.

When signing in to apps via OAuth, or being deeplinked to features like Pages that require authentication, users with multiple accounts in session will be asked which account to use to continue to the app or feature.

When switching an account, as with sign-out or SAML session expiration, notifications will be sent to the other browser tabs open, ensuring that stale sessions and tabs don't result in confusion over which account is being used.
items.title: Multi-account support on GitHub.com

items.content_html:
Summary

This ship brings user-configured alert rules to the organization-level.

Anyone who can enable Dependabot alerts at the organization level will be able to:

  • Create, edit, activate, or deactivate alert rules across an organization
  • Select all or a subset of repositories for rules to apply to
  • Create rules for auto-dismissing false positives, snoozing until patch, and opening Dependabot pull requests.
items.title: Dependabot Alerts: Organization-Level Alert Rules

items.content_html:
Summary

Following the delivery of repository and organization level custom roles and fine-grained permissions, we will deliver this same model at the enterprise level.

Intended Outcome

Least-privilege permissions are important at every layer of account access, from apps to users. Enterprise roles will allow more people to get work done at the enterprise level, without exposing enterprise customers to more risk by granting the highly privileged enterprise owner role.

While most users don't need to interact with the enterprise, there are quite a few highly-sensitive actions that enterprise administrators take, such as setting up SAML, creating organizations, and registering webhooks. We will allow enterprise administrators to enable a member to do one of these things without letting them do all of them, to reduce their risk profile.

There are also less-risky activities, such as reading the audit log, putting up announcement banners, and verifying domains for members. To reduce friction while getting things done, enterprise administrators will be able to grant these permissions to members widely (as needed) without worrying about providing broad access to highly privileged actions.

How will it work?

Like repository and organization custom roles, enterprise owners will be able to create custom roles that contain a set of permissions against the enterprise object. Fine-grained permissions, such as those listed in the examples above, will be made available to craft these custom roles. These enterprise-level fine-grained permissions will work against the UK and API. When assigned to a member of an enterprise, an enterprise-level custom role will allow the user to access certain parts of the enterprise settings, and take certain actions, depending on the permissions in the role.
items.title: Enterprise custom roles and permissions

items.content_html:
Summary

Dependabot version updates creates updates to proactively update out-of-date dependencies. It currently creates one pull request per dependency, but that doesn't make sense for every repository. This feature will allow maintainers to configure their updates to group certain sets of dependencies together.

This is a continuation from the public beta: https://github.com/github/releases/issues/3174 , https://github.com/github/roadmap-internal/issues/299 , #148
And the private beta: https://github.com/github/releases/issues/2914

Intended Outcome

This will help developers better manage the many PRs that Dependabot opens.

How will it work?

Once the developer specifies grouping rules in their dependabot.yml file, they will start seeing Dependabot open PRs with multiple dependencies based on those rules.
items.title: Dependabot Grouped Version Updates GA

items.content_html:
Summary

As an enterprise customer, you have the ability to assign the security manager role to any team in an organization. When applied, it gives every member of that team permissions to manage security alerts and settings across your organization, as well as read all repositories in the organization. Further, you have the ability to create repository-level custom security roles with any of the following security manager permissions to a user or team:

  • View secret scanning
  • Dismiss secret scanning
  • View code scanning
  • Dismiss code scanning
  • Delete code scanning alerts
  • View Dependabot alerts
  • Dismiss Dependabot alerts

Enterprises wanting more personalized control over security manager permissions for their organization will benefit from upcoming enhancements. The enhancements will offer advanced control over security permissions, meeting growing demands for custom access levels.

Intended Outcome

This feature aims to give you advanced control over security permissions, accommodating your increasing need for customized access levels.

How will it work?

The security manager role will continue to exist, but will be enhanced so that you can assign the role to individual users in addition to teams at the organization level.

Moreover, enterprises will be able to create customized security manager roles at the organization level using the listed security permissions. These custom roles can have a combination of organization-wide permissions (like viewing the organization's audit log) and repository-specific permissions (such as allowing Dependabot alert view access) for all organization's repositories. Learn more about organization custom roles.
items.title: Security manager improvements and custom organization security roles

items.content_html:
Summary

Fine-grained PATs today are limited to only the user or organization namespace they are created for. This hinders inner-source use, where repositories in another organization in your enterprise are marked internal . With this change, fine-grained PATs will optionally be able to access internal repositories from the same enterprise, if the token is scoped to an enterprise-owned organization.

Intended Outcome

Inner-source is a critical feature for enterprise developers collaborating on GitHub, allowing them to share code and dependencies within their enterprise freely. Supporting that in fine-grained PATs makes it easier to use these tokens in inner-source scenarios.

How will it work?

A checkbox will appear in the fine-grained PAT creation settings when an enterprise-owned organization is chosen as the resource owner. This checkbox will be checked by default, and when checked, indicates that the token is allowed to access inner-sourced data in the enterprise that owns the chosen organization.
items.title: Fine-grained PAT support for inner-source repositories

items.content_html:
Summary

You'll gain an enhanced view of the security risk page allowing you to see a count per repository of security alerts by alert severity or security feature.

Intended Outcome

Today, enterprises users need to be able to view a total count of alerts by severity or by security feature for a group of repositories.

This feature aims to give users dynamic views to enable users to quickly and easily identify the most critical security risks and prioritize their remediation efforts.

How will it work?

Users will be presented with a toggle on the security risk page to switch between two different row-level presentations: a sum of alerts by alert severity across all security features, and a sum of alerts by security feature across all alert severities.
items.title: Enhancing the security risk page with grouped alert counts

items.content_html:
Summary

We are providing users with the ability to set column limits on the board layout, based off of the number of items in a specific board column. These can be set per column, and are unique to each board layout.

Intended Outcome

By setting and visually highlighting limits on the number of items in a column on a board, users and teams will be able to prioritize their work through the different stages of development. This will increase focus and clarity on the most important work items.

How will it work?

Users will be able to set a per-column limit for the number of work items in a board column that is unique to each board. The count of items and column limit will be surfaced at the top of a board column in a pill (ex: 4/8), and it will be visually highlighted when the limit is reached to indicate to a user that they have reached the limit. Users will not be restricted to moving new items to a column, so it acts as a "soft" limit.
items.title: Projects: Board column limits

items.content_html:
Summary

We are providing users with the ability to specify a field as a swimlane on their boards, allowing them to view their items in a horizontal grouping to visually separate and distinguish between work that belongs to different workstreams, team members, or priorities.

Intended Outcome

By providing users with the ability to specify a field as a swimlane on their boards, we can help them with tasks such as

  • Viewing high priority items alongside items with lower priority, to help draw attention to the most important work and what requires immediate attention
  • Viewing different work streams side-by-side to view the progress of the work for ongoing projects and across teams in a single view
  • Viewing items across team members to see how work breaks down within the team and how it is progressing together

This swimlane view gives users a single zoomed out or stacked view that allows them to stay in one place, without losing the context of how this work compares to each other and is progressing together.

How will it work?

Users will be able to specify a field as a swimlane that is unique to each board. The swimlanes act as a horizontal grouping on board layouts, and items will be able to be moved between swimlanes to make adjustments and update the field value.
items.title: Projects: Board swimlanes

items.content_html:
Summary

Users will be able to select a Slice by field that pulls all field values into a panel on the left side, with the project items associated with those values in the view on the right side. Clicking through the values in the panel will filter and adjust the items that appear in the view, allowing users to quickly page through their items and make adjustments.

Intended Outcome

By providing users with the ability to create this view on their projects, we can help them accomplish tasks such as

  • Visually separating and breaking down epics from the individual tasks by the Tracked by field, giving a hierarchical view of your items powered by tasklists to understand how larger work items are progressing in a single view
  • Planning out current and upcoming iterations by the Iteration field, allowing users to quickly make adjustments to when work will begin if plans change
  • Understanding team capacity with by the Assignee field, breaking down work items by each distinct assignee and giving an easy canvas to move items between team members to reassign work

How will it work?

Users will be able to specify a Slice by field on any of their table, board, or roadmap layouts. The panel allows a user to select a value from the list that populates and filters the work items that appear in the view on the right.
items.title: Projects: Configure a `Slice by` field

items.content_html:
Summary

At both the enterprise and organization levels, you will be able to easily filter the security overview data by repository properties, giving you the ability to more efficiently analyze and manage security risks.

Intended Outcome

Enterprises users have long-requested the ability to group their repositories for easier monitoring of code security status within security overview. Users have specifically requested the ability to filter the risk and coverage views and alert-centric view in security overview by a specific subset of repositories, rather than having to look at all repositories at once.

How will it work?

With this feature, repository properties will be automatically available for filtering via the search bar. This means that you can easily search for specific repositories and filter results based on various repository properties you have setup.
items.title: Repository properties integration with security overview

items.content_html:
Summary

At the organization level, you will be able to enhance the security of your repositories by easily choosing the security-extended query suite when enabling code scanning default setup for multiple repositories.

Intended Outcome

Enterprises users have requested the ability to enable CodeQL at scale and use the security-extended query suite. Currently, the only way to enable CodeQL with the security-extended query suite is at the repository level. This creates a significant workload for users and leads to dissatisfaction with the process.

This feature makes that job easier.

How will it work?

With this feature, you will be able choose between the security-extended and the default query suite when enabling repositories at the organization level when using the "enable all" feature or the multi-repo enablement feature on the security coverage page.
items.title: Code scanning default setup makes it possible to use security-extended CodeQL query suite across your organization

items.content_html:
Summary

At the enterprise level, you will be able to view a trend of security feature enablement and security alerts in order to analyze your security program's performance.

Intended Outcome

Today, enterprise users can see only the current status of security alerts and security feature enablement at the enterprise level. It's not possible to get a historical view of trends across your enterprise. With this feature, users will be able to see a trend of security feature enablement and security alerts at the enterprise level.

How will it work?

We will offer two new pages in security overview at the enterprise level similar to what we'll offer at the organization level: security coverage trends and risk trends that will house trends graphs for the following security features:

  • Dependabot alerts
  • Code scanning alerts
  • Secret scanning alerts
  • Push protection (enablement trends graph only)
  • GitHub Advanced Security (enablement trends graph only)
items.title: View a trend of security feature enablement/security alerts for your enterprise

items.content_html:
Summary

This feature enables you to export data on the security coverage and security risk pages in either CSV or JSON formats, providing a more efficient way to analyze and manipulate data.

Intended Outcome

Enterprise users require the ability to analyze data using various creative approaches not intended to be supported by the product. This feature provides users with the ability to analyze and manipulate data more efficiently, improving overall productivity and data analysis.

How will it work?

You will be able to click the export button on the security coverage or security risk page and select the desired export format, either CSV or JSON. Data from all pages within the view will be exported.
items.title: Export security coverage and security risk data in security overview to CSV or JSON

items.content_html:
Summary

This feature enables you to generate a report of security alerts occurring during a specified period and export the results in either CSV or PDF formats.

Intended Outcome

Enterprise users must comply with strict security regulations that require producing transactional reports of security alerts. The reports must meet specific requirements and, generally, must be generated by the security vendor directly. This feature streamlines the compliance reporting process, enabling users to generate reports that meet regulatory standards.

How will it work?

You will be able to specify a reporting period and generate a report of security alerts that occurred during that period. The report will be able to be generated in either CSV or PDF format.
items.title: Code security transaction report in CSV and PDF formats

items.content_html:
Summary

This feature enables you to filter security overview data by programming language, providing a more efficient way to analyze and manage security risks at both enterprise and organizational levels.

Intended Outcome

Enterprise users have requested the ability to filter by programming language, streamlining the process of identifying and resolving security risks.

How will it work?

In the security overview, you can utilize the search bar located at the top of each page, such as the security risk and coverage pages. The search bar is a useful tool that allows you to manage data on the page efficiently.

With this feature, programming language filters will be automatically available via the search bar.
items.title: Programming language filter in security overview

items.content_html:
Summary

This feature provides for addiitonal views of code security—at the enterprise and repository level, presenting critical metrics to evaluate your security and identify areas for improvement.

Intended Outcome

Security managers face challenges in analyzing the extensive data generated by security products. The volume of alerts can be overwhelming, leading to critical questions such as, "Are we making progress?" "Where should we focus our efforts?" and "What are our priorities?" This dashboard enables security managers to make informed decisions, prioritize tasks, and monitor progress, enhancing code security and ultimately reducing vulnerability.

How will it work?

The security overview dashboard will serve as the primary view for code security, providing a comprehensive analysis of critical metrics that drive behavior. You'll be able to access the dashboard by clicking on the security tab, displaying a visually intuitive, one-page view of the most relevant information to achieve your code security objectives.
items.title: Comprehensive code security analysis with an enterprise-level and repository-level security overview dashboard
